title: The worst airports in the world revealed including Port Harcourt in Nigeria
text:
View
comments
For many, a holiday starts from the moment they set foot in the airport.
But these airports - that feature delights such as a tent for an arrivals hall and aggressive staff - are likely to bring anyone on cloud nine crashing back to earth.
In its annual review, sleepinginairports. net revealed the worst airports in the world for 2015 - and here MailOnline Travel takes a closer look at some of those that made it into the hall of infamy.
Despite not making the 2014 World's Worst top ten, Port Harcourt in Nigeria tops the pile this year
1. Port Harcourt International Airport, Nigeria (PHC)
Fresh after scooping the honour of being named the Worst Airport in Africa by the website, Port Harcourt Airport in Nigeria comes top of the pile on the world ratings.
Incredibly, Port Harcourt didn't even appear on last year's World's Worst list.
'With virtually no seating, broken air-conditioning and a tent for an Arrivals Hall, it was a struggle for many voters to pass the minimum required amount of time here,' says sleepinginairports.net.
Chinwe Owhoji writes on his one-star Google + review: 'No signs for directions, zero staff management, and the refurbishment work is taking for ever to get completed.'
2. Jeddah King Abdulaziz International Airport, Saudi Arabia
Saudi Arabia's Jeddah King Abdulaziz International Airport came second on the list, with travellers criticising the lack of services, rude immigration officers, lengthy queues and uncomfortable metal chairs.
Saudi Arabia's Jeddah King Abdulaziz International Airport came second on the list
WORST AIRPORTS IN THE WORLD 1. Port Harcourt International Airport (Nigeria)
2. King Abdulaziz International Airport (Jeddah, Saudi Arabia)
3. Tribhuvan International Airport (Kathmandu, Nepal)
4. Tashkent International Airport (Uzbekistan)
5. Simon Bolivar International Airport (Caracas, Venezuela)
6. Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Port au Prince, Haiti)
7. Hamid Karzai International Airport (Kabul, Afghanistan)
8. Tan Son Nhat International Airport (Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam)
9. Benazir Bhutto International Airport (Islamabad, Pakistan)
10. Beauvais-Tille International Airport (Paris)
WORST AIRPORTS IN EUROPE 1. Beauvais-Tille International Airport (France)
2. Santorini Thira National Airport (Greece)
3. Rhodes International Airport (Greece)
4. Crete Heraklion International Airport (Greece)
5. Berlin Schönefeld International Airport (Germany)
6. Corfu International Airport (Greece)
7. Rome Ciampino International Airport (Italy)
8. Brussels Charleroi International Airport (Belgium)
9. Bergamo Orio al Serio International Airport (Italy)
10. London Luton International Airport (England)
Results from sleepinginairports.co.uk 2016 survey
People smoking in the non-smoking areas and bad smells wafting through from the bathrooms were also highlighted by visitors.
However there could be some relief for those flying into Saudi Arabia imminently - the new airport is believed to be ready to open in mid-2016.
3. Kathmandu Tribhuvan International Airport, Nepal
In third spot on the list comes Kathmandu's only international Airport.
The airport has been described as 'a bus station in an impoverished neighbourhood'.
You can see why some people have described the airport in Kathmandu as more like 'a bus station'
The lack of cleanliness was again a particular concern, as was the lack of soap, air-conditioning and filthy smoking room.
There have been some stresses on the site however - in March this year a Turkish Airlines plane skidded off the runway, and in April the airport was closed due to the devastating earthquake that killed more than 9,000 people.
4. Tashkent International Airport, Uzbekistan
Uzbekistan's Tashkent International Airport was fourth on the list, with poor crowd control the main grievance.
One traveller remarked: 'The person behind you will be trying to cut in front by subtly ramming their baggage cart into the back of your legs. Hold your ground!'
Tashkent Airport in Uzbekistan secured fourth place in the top ten worst airports in the world
Another added: 'Elbows are required should you hope to maintain your spot in line, since any form of line-up or crowd control seems to be virtually non-existent.'
Extensive queues throughout the airport were also major grievances, as well as the common problem of finding suitable seating.
5. Caracas Simón Bolívar International Airport, Venezuela
'Chaotic, uncomfortable and dull,' was the general theme among people rating Caracas Simón Bolívar International Airport in Venezuela.
While free Wi-Fi and two private lounges were highlighted as positives, poor quality and choice of food, inadequate seating and low-standard bathroom facilities saw this airport hit number five in the rankings.
Customers to Caracas Simón Bolívar International Airport have been warned to secure their luggage
THE 2015 SURVEY Amost 26,500 people responded to sleepingairports.co.uk's 2016 survey that ranked every aspect of the airport experience.
Travellers were asked to rate the following on a scale of 1 (awful) - 5 (excellent):
Overall Airport Experience Terminal Cleanliness Services, Facilities & Things To Do Customer Service Comfort Sleepability Back in April this year MailOnline reported how tourists travelling to Venezuela were being warned to take extra precautions with their luggage following a spate of thefts at the country's main international airport.
In the first four months of this year, 42 workers at Simón Bolívar International Airport Maiquetia were arrested for stealing from tourists' luggage.
6. Port au Prince Toussaint Louverture International Airport, Haiti
Bathrooms that are rarely cleaned, aggressive staff, and a lack of seating means Port au Prince makes number six in this years unwanted list.
Writing on Google + visitor Salaam Muhammad describes how it was 'the worst airport he had ever seen.'
'No restaurants, no nothing, very minimal air conditioning,' he says.
Renee F, who is from Haiti, goes one step further when she writes: 'The airport is a disgrace and I am ashamed of it for myself , for my compatriots and for Toussaint Louverture whose name is on the building.'
The standard of the facilities at Port au Prince airport in Haiti even anger the locals
7. Kabul Hamid Karzai International Airport, Afghanistan
Cleanliness, comfort and friendliness of staff were highlighted as the main concerns of visitors to Kabul Hamid Karzai International Airport in Afghanistan.
However, the political instability was highlighted as possibly being a factor in reviews.
Passenger Luke Matthews described his experience at the airport as the 'most terrible of his life,' in a one-star Google + review.
Kabul Airport is attempting to reclaim it's place out of the war-torn country of Afghanistan
8. Ho Chi Minh City Tân Sơn Nhất International Airport, Vietnam
The survey reported that customers complained of poor Wi-Fi, dirty bathrooms and poor selection of food outlets at Ho Chi Minh airport.
Other claims made by passengers travelling through the Vietnamese airports were that you could be fast-tracked through queues if you paid.
Quote: : 'Please be cautious with all associates you meet, especially when dealing with money.'
Writing on his three-star Google + review, Raymond Low says: 'Basic, uninspiring but functional airport. Customs, immigration and general airport staff unfriendly, little spoken English and sour faced.'
Passengers are warned to be careful with their money at Ho Chi Minh airport in Vietnam
9. Islamabad Benazir Bhutto International Airport, Pakistan
It's a welcome move down the list for Islamabad Benazir Bhutto Airport, which topped the pile for 2014.
Customers have likened Pakistan's Islamabad Benazir Bhutto International Airport to 'a central prison' adding: 'Many of the touts and taxi drivers loot people at the airport and outside'.
Islamabad Benazir Bhutto Airport has been described as like 'a prison
Tourists also criticised the absence of crowd control, 'pervasive corruption', inconsistent security checks and the overall lack of cleanliness and technology.
However, certain improvements have been made in the last year that may explain the airport's shift down the list.
More counters have been opened for baggage and immigration, and the bathrooms and food outlets have been improved.
10. Paris Beauvais-Tille International Airport outside Paris, France
Paris Beauvais-Tille was voted the worst airport in Europe by those responding to the survey
Paris Beauvais-Tille was voted the worst airport in Europe by those responding to the survey, and it just sneaked into the top ten.
Poor hygiene, a lack of adequate seating, and the manners of staff were highlighted as the main grievances.
A month ago Olivia Webster wrote on Google +: 'The single most disorganised, unpleasant, vile fetid excuse for an airport that I've ever had the misfortune to visit.' She rated it as one star out of five.
